boardgame.name: The Cryptid Conundrum
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Alien invaders have kidnapped the leader of the Space Rangers, can the heroes find him, and can they solve the alien's devious puzzles?

The Cryptid Conundrum is a campaign for the Amazing Tales role-playing game. It's set in the far future, where humans and aliens work together to explore the farthest reaches of space. The Cryptid Conundrum includes

Four adventures, each good for hours of play
Four full colour illustrations by Ayu Marques
A Cryptid Code wheel for you to cut out and make with your child
A collection of puzzles and mysteries to print out and solve


To resolve the Cryptid Crisis the heroes will have to

Defuse a ticking bomb
Conduct an investigation on the ocean planet of Rygon Four
Deal with smugglers and criminals on the desert planet of Solarium Prime
Turn back an alien invasion


Solve the Cryptid's fiendish puzzles

boardgame.name: Air & Armor: Operational Armored Warfare in Europe – Designer Signature Edition
boardgame.description:
Air & Armor: Operational Armored Warfare in Europe, Designer Signature Edition marks the return of one of the most highly rated wargames on modern warfare ever published. Air & Armor is a company level simulation of a Hypothetical Soviet attack on West Germany in the mid-1980s.

It depicts the collision of the Soviet 8th Guards Army and elements of the U.S. 3rd Infantry Division and West German 12th Panzer Division in a ferocious battle around the German city of Wurzburg.

This new edition is lovingly recreated with new map artwork, new unit counters, new unit values and updated rules.

Air & Armor employs a highly interactive game system with asymmetric rules modeling the different Command & control techniques of each alliance. The game simulates all of the major aspects of modern warfare: reconnaissance, combined arms operations, air, helicopter and artillery strikes, chemical and electronic warfare and engineering. Multiple levels of hidden intelligence produce a true “fog of war” and provide plenty of opportunities for deception, surprise and ambush. Play this game to find out what it really might have been like to command a division in battle.

Based on detailed research from Warsaw Pact archives now available, this new edition includes a completely revised Order of Battle featuring one East German and four Soviet Divisions.
Air & Armor includes a Basic Game, covering standard armor operations, and an Advanced Game that layers in air and engineering operations and Chemical and electronic warfare. Each game level includes four to six Scenarios, which are complete games in themselves. Extensive Scenario, Player and Designer Notes provide advice on play and historical detail.

Product Information:
Complexity: Medium
Time Scale: 1 Turn = 2 Hours
Map Scale: 1 Mile/hex
Unit Scale: Companies and Battalions
Players: 2-7 players
Solitaire Suitability: Medium
Playing Time: 3 to 8 hours based on Scenario

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: The Annexation of Chiraz
boardgame.description:
The Annexation of Chiraz links five Table Top Teasers or scenarios together in a mini campaign.
They can be played as stand alone battles or sequentially with each impacting on the next.

The year is 1754 and hostilities between those two old adversaries, The Grand Duchy of Lorraine and the Vereinigte Freie Städte (VFS), - the United Free Provinces - a fairly tight agglomeration of countries, small principalities, republics and city states, are continuing.
The Grand Duchy of Lorraine, closely allied to France further to the west, has struggled to maintain her borders for many years against the blatant aggression of the VFS.
The VFS is itself part of a broader alliance known as The Electoral League.
A part of this alliance is the Electorate of Tuetonburg-Fredonia to the south of the VFS and with a small border with Lorraine delineated by the River Surren.
Tuetonburg-Fredonia has in recent years assisted her allies in their conflict with finance and mercenaries but has herself maintained a polite detachment from matters military– things are about to change!

—description from publisher
boardgame.boardgamefamily: Series: mid-18th century Table-top Teasers (Charles S. Grant)
boardgame.boardgameexpansion: Die Kriegskunst: Wargaming the Seven Years War
Principles of War: 18th Century – Warfare in the Age of Reason

boardgame.name: The Wolfenbüttel War
boardgame.description:
The Wolfenbüttel War concerns the hostilities of Charles’ two fictitious mid-eighteenth century combatants, the Grand Duchy of Lorraine and the Vereinigte Freie Städte (VFS). The scenarios are applicable to any horse and musket period with little modification.

Where this mini-campaign differs from its predecessors (Raid on St.Michel, The Annexation of Chiraz) is that it is loosely based on a real campaign – that of the Hundred Days, culminating at Waterloo. The four scenarios and the movements between them are drawn from the battles of Quatre Bras, Ligny, Wavre and Waterloo. However, while the campaign sequence is followed the outcome is far from certain.

The book provides the fictitious background to the war, planning details including the selection of forces, the instructions for each army, table top maps and orders for each side. There are instructions for the game organiser and options for forces in each battle if fought as a stand alone wargame. The book is illustrated with photographs of each battle as it was fought with Charles’ armies. Newspapers and a Who’s Who, not to mention the Ballroom scene, add colour to the story of the Wolfenbüttel War.

—description from the publisher's website

boardgame.name: Pisces: A High-Stakes Fishing Competition
boardgame.description:
The Pisces game is all about fishing, fish, and conservation. The goal is to obtain the maximum points by being the most successful at catching fish and receiving credit for implementing conservation measures to maintain a healthy population. Each fish follows a uniquely structured life cycle that models their real-world dynamics and susceptibility to overfishing, including snapper, tuna, sardines, sharks, mahi mahi, and crabs. Players select which fishing zone and species will present the best fishing opportunities each round. The availability of sea life to catch changes throughout the game, as the fish go through various life cycle stages and are harvested by the players. If they are abundant, they are easy to catch. But if they are overfished, it gets harder, just like in real life. Strategize to protect your stock from overfishing while collecting the boats and gear to tip the odds of a big catch!

-description from designers

boardgame.name: Allegra
boardgame.description:
In Allegra, based on the public card game "Golf", you want to keep your score as low as possible, but to do this sometimes you must help your neighbors along the way.

The deck consists of cards numbered -1 to 11, and in each of the three rounds, each player starts with twelve cards face down in a grid of four columns and three rows. Your rightmost column is also considered to belong to your right-hand neighbor, and likewise your area includes the rightmost column of your left-hand neighbor. Each player reveals any two cards in their area, then the round begins.

On a turn, you either draw the top card of the deck and reveal it, or draw the top card of the discard pile. If you draw from the discard pile, swap that card with any card in your area, then discard the replaced card. If you draw from the deck, you can discard that card (turning any card in your area face up) or you can swap that card with any card in your area.

If you draw from the deck, any other player can knock on the table to indicate that they want this card. You can ignore the knock, or you can give them the card; in the latter case, they then replace one card in their area with this new card, taking the old card in their hand. You then take any one card in their area and swap it for a card in your area, discarding the replaced card. The other player then places the card in their hand into the hole you created when you took one of their cards.

Any time you have three identical cards in a row or column — even a row that includes a card in your left neighbor's rightmost column! — you discard those cards from play.

Whenever one player has all their cards face up, each other player takes one more turn, then players sum the value of the cards in their area (which includes any cards remaining their neighbor's rightmost column). If the player who triggered the end of the round doesn't have the lowest sum, their sum is doubled. The player with the lowest total score after three rounds wins.
boardgame.boardgamehonor: 2021 5 Seasons Best International Card Game Nominee

boardgame.name: Who's the Dude: Now's Not Time for Correctness
boardgame.description:
Now's not time for correctness!
During the five years of his life in Russia, Dude learned a lot of new words and expressions. Now he knows that "get a bream" is not always about fish, and you can throw more than confetti on the fan. Dude is ready to play with the most daring adult company! In this game — 336 new words, including many ambiguous and obscene. They can catch you off guard right after something innocent like ping-pong or ventriloquism. You can adjust the degree of the game and guess ambiguous words using a direct or figurative meaning.

Do you know Dude?
Who's the Dude is a hit party game where you have to explain words and phrases with gestures and an inflatable Dude. Together, you find yourself in strange situations: reincarnate as different people, act out scenes from movies or famous sayings. Dude is ready to become a tool, an object, an animal — use it as you like, as long as the players name the correct answer! The winner is the one who after the fourth round will score the most points for the guessed words.

Take Dude:

To a wild party." And don't forget to take your camera — it's should be capturing.
As a gift to a friend with a good sense of humor.
In the company that loves of charades.
For a stag or hen party. As a gift to the newlyweds, too!


—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: The Third World War: Designer Signature Edition
boardgame.description:
The Third World War, Designer Signature Edition

This edition of The Third World War features many new enhancements and larger counters and is another Classic Reborn!

The complete Third World War game series is included which is comprised of the following four games:

Third World War (subtitled Battle for Germany) is a game of the struggle for central Europe by the forces of NATO and the Warsaw Pact.
Southern Front: Race for the Turkish Straits adds Bulgaria and Romania, reinforced with three Soviet armies and special-capability forces, face Greece, Turkey, and Yugoslavia, thinly reinforced with a few elite units from the U.S., France, and Italy.
Arctic Front: Battle for Norway covers the Soviet Leningrad Front, with its special airborne, amphibious, and arctic-equipped contingents, assault of Norway, reinforced with a few elite units from the U.S., Britain, Canada, and other NATO nations.
Persian Gulf: Battle for the Middle East includes a special "game within a game", covering the diplomatic, political, and military maneuvers by the Soviet Union and the United States in the Middle East before - and leading to - the general outbreak of the Third World War.


For the not faint of heart, combined game rules are provided to cover the entire Third World War that combines all four games in the series for a truly memorable gaming experience.

This Designer Signature edition pays tribute to the classic Frank Chadwick game series by honoring the original game system and keeping it fully intact (no design changes made), while introducing many enhancements for game play purposes.

In terms of superior physical presentation, all aspects have been upgraded, including completely new maps, numerous new player aids, markers, and unit displays, and redesigned and enlarged 9/16" counters. Some of the enhancements made in this edition include:

• All four separate games combined into one, comprehensive package
• Enlarged and redesigned counters from 1/2" to 9/16" size
• Added more information to counters such as: mobility class, stacking value, zoc type, chemical/nuclear/limited military ability
• Enhanced ergonomics are built into the set up and reinforcement charts
• Modified and adjusted unit colors to better distinguish between each other and between NATO/Pact/Neutrals
• Added and modified game markers including Strike markes with values on them, air superiority, weather, objective control, and generic markers
• Combined the seven maps from Third World War, Southern Front, and Arctic Front into four larger maps (22 x 34"), including adding the remainder of Poland and Western Russia; all while keeping the same area of the original games
• Combined four maps from Persian Gulf into two larger (22 x 34") maps
• Added and modified player aids such as: new display to aid with handling unwieldy stacks (use a marker on map to indicate stack of units and put the placement sheet
• Warsaw Pact ground unit counters with one step-loss (disruption) on reverse
• Addition of U.S. F-117 air unit for optional use. Also retains the U.S. F-19 air unit from the original game
• Player aid cards and associated markers, for tracking nuclear conflict level and nuclear attack points (NAPs), air transport points, and victory points
• Markers to indicate Norwegian Sea control and whether the Black Sea Fleet has sortied
• Optional tactical advantage rule
• Color-coding on Warsaw Pact ground unit counters for ease in distinguishing army designation
• Incorporated errata for unit set-up information and reinforcement schedule
• All-new rules treatment backed by many illustrations, an index, and clarifications and examples of play to reduce potential questions.

Product Information:

Complexity: 6 out of 10
Solitaire Suitability: 8 out of 10 (no hidden units)
Time Scale: 1 week per turn
Map Scale: 45 km per hex
Unit Scale: divisions, with some brigades and regiments, 100 aircraft per air unit
Players: one to two per individual game, one to eight for combined campaign
Playing Time: 6-10 hours per game, 36+ hours for full combined campaign


—description from the publisher

Game Scale:
Game Turn: One Week
Hex: 28 miles / 45 kilometers
Units: Brigade to Division

Six 22 x 34" full color mapsheets

Twenty-four Diplomacy cards
Four six-sided dice

Solitaire Playability: High

Players: 2 to 7

boardgame.name: The LOOP
The LOOP: Dr Foo strikes back...back...back
Pętla
Петля
boardgame.description:
The LOOP is a quirky co-operative game in which you battle the evil Dr. Faux. Play a Temporal Agent in four different game modes, full of new challenges and replay value. Gather powerful artifacts, defy the Doctor's duplicates, and sabotage his maniacal machine. Make the most of your cards and master the LOOP to use them multiple times in impressive chains — but the Doctor isn't going to make this easy on you!

The evil Dr. Faux has built a terrrrible time machine! With the help of the duplicates of himself that he is creating through the ages, he aims to carry out his Omniscience 2000 project to become master of the universe. But the rifts that he is opening in spacetime will probably destroy quantum space way sooner...

Join the Agency in the shoes of one of its most legendary agents, and co-operate to foil the fiendish schemes of Dr. Faux, using quirky but still powerful artifacts.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Lost Worlds: "Brimstone" The Fire Giant
boardgame.description:
Lost Worlds is the most popular entry in Alfred Leonardi's line of book games, which also includes Ace of Aces. Each player has a character card and a booklet (and sometimes special Tactics, Luck, or Spell cards) for one of about fifty (and growing) medieval-fantasy characters. Characters can range from barbarian warriors to animated skeletons to elven archers to unicorns — even two different dragons. Booklets are traded and, as each player selects a move, a reference grid in the books determine the results (wounds, off-balance maneuvers, and so on). Combat continues until one fighter or the other expires.

An interesting feature of the Lost Worlds system is that, under some versions of the rules, characters may improve their abilities as they gain experience. In theory, you are supposed to keep track of your progress with each character, and if one is utterly killed, it will have to start over without its improved skills.

Part of the Lost Worlds series of books.


This book represents Brimstone the Fire Giant a character in the Lost Worlds Series of combat picture games, and is playable with all other books that carry the Lost Worlds logo. each book is unique and has its own special qualities. Collect them and discover for yourself their magic.

(From the booklet: Lost Worlds: "Brimstone" the Fire Giant)

boardgame.name: Module 1: Rise of the Redhats
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The late 21st century has never looked so grim, but it's not without hope.

Welcome to The Orichite Age, an episodic expansion series to the critically acclaimed Entromancy: A Cyberpunk Fantasy RPG. Over the course of several brand new modules, The Orichite Age will bring players from a cybertech-dominated future to a magic-rich past, with new stories, character options, gear, cybernetics, adversaries, and encounters.

Module 1: Rise of the Redhats updates the Entromancy world state with lore recaps from Technomancy: Book Two of the Nightpath Trilogy and Shadowmancy: Book Three of the Nightpath Trilogy, and adds the new Troll player option and four new adversary types, including the Unaligned Firebrand, Firebrand Ringleader, Shadow Dragon, and Technodragon.

boardgame.name: Merchants of Sol
boardgame.description:
As Merchants of Sol, You're the Captain of a merchant ship and head of one of the most powerful families in the solar system. Your goal is to reach all of your destinations whilst collecting as much cargo as you can along the way. There will be many challenges to overcome.

To travel through the void unmarked by hardship is a fool’s dream. The system is filled with pirates, mutants, endless bureaucracy, and —worst of all— other merchants.

A keen mind can turn the tide. Just remember, even for the saltiest of captains, Lady Luck can be quite fickle.

Merchants of Sol is a game for 2-6 players age 12+. Gameplay averages out to about 20-30 minutes per player. A key element of the game is its narration. As you draw cards to determine your fate, each destination and event has an exciting blend of story and facts about our solar system including the planets, dwarf planets, and moons that fill it.

Unique design and simple mechanics involving subtle strategy ensure a wonderfully balanced play experience. Every play session will be different as there are multiple paths to victory. Amazing artwork graces every surface making it as fun a game to look at as it is to play.

Fair winds and following seas!

—description from the publisher

From the back of the book:
Azlana is the daughter of a dark elf priestess and her human captive. Although raised by her mothe rin the Underdark, he mixed blood was discovered by another house of drow, and Azlana was made a slave ... . After two years ... Azlana was finally able to escape ... . Azlana had become a highly skilled warrior. She put those skills to use one night fighting a roving thief. The incident was witnessed by a red dragon who saw her value and quickly befriended her... the dragon convinced her to stay with him in order to help guard his treasure... The dragon ... taught her spells for producing fireballs and poisonous smoke ... ."

listing.notes:
[size=14][b][u]Comments:[/u][/b][/size]
To see other items that I have for sale (and perhaps mitigate shipping costs) enter the following into your browser: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekmarket/user/Paladin82Y . I will do my best to make this an easy transaction for you. You can review my track record of success here… https://boardgamegeek.com/geekmarket/user/Paladin82Y/feedback. Also, have been on ebay since 1997 with 100% positive feedback. Note that I am not a store but just a gamer like you (although one that lost his mind and purchased waaaay too many games over the last 30 years). I have tried to accurately describe my offerings from a gamer's perspective. If you are a collector or re-seller and need more details, just let me know. In general, I'm mindful about the condition of my games while playing, but I am not a rabid preservationist... I often discard advertisements and inserts (so please assume that if an insert was originally included in the box that it is gone - if an insert is important to you, please ask about it). Furthermore, most played games (with cards) were sleeved during play... but unless specifically and explicitly noted otherwise, any sleeves will have been removed before the game was offered for sale.
[size=14][b][u]Condition Notes:[/u][/b][/size] Smoke-free home. Pet-free home. COVID-free home. Still in shrinkwrap.
[b][u]Edition Notes:[/u][/b] English.
[size=14][b][u]Shipping Notes:[/u][/b][/size] Ask me about how you can create an order where there will be no charge to ship this item as an add-on item if you purchase a big-box game at the same time.
You are welcome to reduce the shipping costs to $0.00 by picking up the item in Waukee. Although it is more rare now, I do sometimes attend one of the many local Game Nights close to Waukee, IA (see https://www.boardgamegeek.com/guild/1365) and it might be possible to meet there. Otherwise--Yes, I will gladly combine orders to reduce your per-item shipping costs. (To find other items to add to your order see http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekmarket/user/Paladin82Y).
When placing an order, please provide a contact phone number--this is ONLY in case there are shipping issues--I am NOT planning to call you. Also, please provide a direct/external (non-BGG) email address.
Finally, if at all possible, please provide a business (rather than a residential) shipping address and let me know that the address you are providing is a business address (this may expedite delivery).
[size=14][b][u]Payment Notes:[/u][/b][/size] **Note that the listed offered price includes a small discount for a cash (cash, money order, Amazon Gift Card, western union) payment. I cannot include the discount for payments made via Paypal.
[b][i]US buyers:[/i][/b] When placing the order, let me know if you would like to purchase the optional insurance offered by the shipping company. I cannot remember ever having any material problems, but theoretically there is some risk. If the receiver (you) does NOT request (and does NOT pay extra for) insurance (decision is totally up to you) then the receiver (you) agrees to assume responsibility for lost or damaged packages. I know that this paragraph sounds scary, but my lawyer makes me include this -- again, this is probably a non-issue -- I have never had a package that I shipped go missing and think that I have had two people mention extremely minor blemishes incurred during shipping in the last 600 BGG items that I have shipped. See the [i][b]Info from Seller[/b][/i] Section below for more critically important details on payment options.
[b][i]non-US buyers:[/i][/b] See the [i][b]Info from Seller[/b][/i] Section below for more critically important details on shipping and payment options.

boardgame.name: Lost Worlds: Meresin – Dwarf with Warhammer
boardgame.description:
Lost Worlds is the most popular entry in Alfred Leonardi's line of book games, which also includes Ace of Aces. Each player has a character card and a booklet (and sometimes special Tactics, Luck, or Spell cards) for one of about fifty (and growing) medieval-fantasy characters. Characters can range from barbarian warriors to animated skeletons to elven archers to unicorns — even two different dragons. Booklets are traded and, as each player selects a move, a reference grid in the books determine the results (wounds, off-balance maneuvers, and so on). Combat continues until one fighter or the other expires.

An interesting feature of the Lost Worlds system is that, under some versions of the rules, characters may improve their abilities as they gain experience. In theory, you are supposed to keep track of your progress with each character, and if one is utterly killed, it will have to start over without its improved skills.

Part of the Lost Worlds series of books.


From inside front page with User Summary:

This book represents "Amara Wintersword : Female Barbarian with Axe" in the LOST WORLDS combat book games and is playable, with all other LOST WORLDS books. Each book is unique and has its own special qualities.

listing.notes:
[size=14][b][u]Comments:[/u][/b][/size]
To see other items that I have for sale (and perhaps mitigate shipping costs) enter the following into your browser: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekmarket/user/Paladin82Y . I will do my best to make this an easy transaction for you. You can review my track record of success here… https://boardgamegeek.com/geekmarket/user/Paladin82Y/feedback. Also, have been on ebay since 1997 with 100% positive feedback. Note that I am not a store but just a gamer like you (although one that lost his mind and purchased waaaay too many games over the last 30 years). I have tried to accurately describe my offerings from a gamer's perspective. If you are a collector or re-seller and need more details, just let me know. In general, I'm mindful about the condition of my games while playing, but I am not a rabid preservationist... I often discard advertisements and inserts (so please assume that if an insert was originally included in the box that it is gone - if an insert is important to you, please ask about it). Furthermore, most played games (with cards) were sleeved during play... but unless specifically and explicitly noted otherwise, any sleeves will have been removed before the game was offered for sale.
[size=14][b][u]Condition Notes:[/u][/b][/size] Smoke-free home. Pet-free home. COVID-free home. Still in shrinkwrap.
[b][u]Edition Notes:[/u][/b] English.
[size=14][b][u]Shipping Notes:[/u][/b][/size] Ask me about how you can create an order where there will be no charge to ship this item as an add-on item if you purchase a big-box game at the same time.
You are welcome to reduce the shipping costs to $0.00 by picking up the item in Waukee. Although it is more rare now, I do sometimes attend one of the many local Game Nights close to Waukee, IA (see https://www.boardgamegeek.com/guild/1365) and it might be possible to meet there. Otherwise--Yes, I will gladly combine orders to reduce your per-item shipping costs. (To find other items to add to your order see http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekmarket/user/Paladin82Y).
When placing an order, please provide a contact phone number--this is ONLY in case there are shipping issues--I am NOT planning to call you. Also, please provide a direct/external (non-BGG) email address.
Finally, if at all possible, please provide a business (rather than a residential) shipping address and let me know that the address you are providing is a business address (this may expedite delivery).
[size=14][b][u]Payment Notes:[/u][/b][/size] **Note that the listed offered price includes a small discount for a cash (cash, money order, Amazon Gift Card, western union) payment. I cannot include the discount for payments made via Paypal.
[b][i]US buyers:[/i][/b] When placing the order, let me know if you would like to purchase the optional insurance offered by the shipping company. I cannot remember ever having any material problems, but theoretically there is some risk. If the receiver (you) does NOT request (and does NOT pay extra for) insurance (decision is totally up to you) then the receiver (you) agrees to assume responsibility for lost or damaged packages. I know that this paragraph sounds scary, but my lawyer makes me include this -- again, this is probably a non-issue -- I have never had a package that I shipped go missing and think that I have had two people mention extremely minor blemishes incurred during shipping in the last 600 BGG items that I have shipped. See the [i][b]Info from Seller[/b][/i] Section below for more critically important details on payment options.
[b][i]non-US buyers:[/i][/b] See the [i][b]Info from Seller[/b][/i] Section below for more critically important details on shipping and payment options.

boardgame.name: Lost Worlds: "Ursa" Bugbear
boardgame.description:
Lost Worlds is the most popular entry in Alfred Leonardi's line of book games, which also includes Ace of Aces. Each player has a character card and a booklet (and sometimes special Tactics, Luck, or Spell cards) for one of about fifty (and growing) medieval-fantasy characters. Characters can range from barbarian warriors to animated skeletons to elven archers to unicorns — even two different dragons. Booklets are traded and, as each player selects a move, a reference grid in the books determine the results (wounds, off-balance maneuvers, and so on). Combat continues until one fighter or the other expires.

An interesting feature of the Lost Worlds system is that, under some versions of the rules, characters may improve their abilities as they gain experience. In theory, you are supposed to keep track of your progress with each character, and if one is utterly killed, it will have to start over without its improved skills.

Part of the Lost Worlds series of books.

Lost Worlds is the most popular entry in Alfred Leonardi's line of book games, which also includes Ace of Aces. Part of the Lost Worlds series of books.


From back of the book:

Zocchi the dicemaker is famous for the high-quality little gambling stones he makes for players worldwide. But few people realize he is also a powerful magician, one of the oldest in the world. Among the inner circles of mages, he is known as "The Ancient One." If you are foolish enough to challenge him, you will discover that not only can he cast powerful spells, he can use one of his magic dice bags as amace or a shield. And you do NOT want to see what can come o ut of his magical top hat .."

boardgame.name: Lost Worlds: Giant Goblin With Mace and Shield
boardgame.description:
Lost Worlds is the most popular entry in Alfred Leonardi's line of book games, which also includes Ace of Aces. Each player has a character card and a booklet (and sometimes special Tactics, Luck, or Spell cards) for one of about fifty (and growing) medieval-fantasy characters. Characters can range from barbarian warriors to animated skeletons to elven archers to unicorns — even two different dragons. Booklets are traded and, as each player selects a move, a reference grid in the books determine the results (wounds, off-balance maneuvers, and so on). Combat continues until one fighter or the other expires.

An interesting feature of the Lost Worlds system is that, under some versions of the rules, characters may improve their abilities as they gain experience. In theory, you are supposed to keep track of your progress with each character, and if one is utterly killed, it will have to start over without its improved skills.

Part of the Lost Worlds series of books.

boardgame.name: Sfida al Trono degli Eoni
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

In Starfinder – Sfida al Trono degli Eoni gli eroi sono ingaggiati per trasportare un carico di provviste su un pianeta avvolto dalla nebbia nell’Immensità. Lungo il viaggio scoprono che la colonia dei Mondi del Patto è stata occupata da un piccolo contingente militare proveniente dall’Impero Stellare Azlanti. I personaggi devono liberare l’insediamento dai suoi spietati oppressori e, quando lo fanno, scoprono che gli Azlanti hanno portato via uno dei coloni di Nakondis, una loro vecchia amica, e un motore di astronave sperimentale scoperto sul pianeta. Riusciranno i nostri eroi a salvare Cedona e tenere lontano dalle grinfie degli Azlanti il motore sperimentale o saranno schiacciati dalla potenza del Trono degli Eoni come i tanti che hanno osato sfidarlo?

Questa raccolta comprende l’intero Ciclo Sfida al Trono degli Eoni e include:

• “L’Estensione dell’Impero”, un’avventura di Starfinder per personaggi di 1° livello, di Ron Lundeen.

• “Fuga dalla Luna Prigione”, un’avventura di Starfinder per personaggi di 3° livello, di Eleanor Ferron.

• “Lo Stratagemma del Motore Runico”, un’avventura di Starfinder per personaggi di 5° livello, di Larry Wilhelm.

• Un archivio di nuove e affascinanti creature, da draghi radioattivi a gigantesche nubi di melma divoratrice, di Patrick Brennan, Ron Lundeen, Joe Pasini, Owen K.C. Stephens, Eleanor Ferron, David N. Ross, Ian Eller e Larry Wilhelm.

• La storia e la descrizione di Nakondis, una colonia dei Mondi del Patto, e di Approdo di Madelon, il suo insediamento più importante, oltre a un nuovo tema dei personaggi, il colonizzatore, di Ron Lundeen, più uno scorcio del pianeta natale dell’Impero Stellare Azlanti, di Owen K.C. Stephens.

• Una raccolta di avanzate astronavi costruite e pilotate nell’Impero Stellare Alzanti, di Lyz Liddell, le statistiche e planimetrie di un nuovo vascello da esplorazione dell’Impero Stellare Alzanti, di Ron Lundeen, di un lussuoso vascello regale Azlanti, di Larry Wilhelm, nonché di un’astronave da guardia Azlanti, e infine uno sguardo a una stazione spaziale ai bordi dell’Impero Stellare, di Eleanor Ferron.

• Uno sguardo approfondito alla cultura, alla storia e ai territori dell’espansionista Impero Stellare Azlanti, oltre a una raccolta di equipaggiamenti Azlanti di natura magica e tecnologica, di Robert G. McCreary, con Jason Keeley e Lyz Liddell.

• Consigli su come proseguire la campagna dopo lo scontro finale e indicazioni sul potere che l’Impero Stellare Azlanti acquisirebbe se gli eroi dovessero fallire, di Tracy Barnett.

• E molto altro ancora!


Translation courtesy of Google:

In Starfinder - Challenge to the Throne of Aeons, the heroes are hired to transport a load of supplies to a planet shrouded in immensity by fog. Along the way they discover that the colony of the Covenant Worlds was occupied by a small military contingent from the Azlanti Star Empire. The characters must free the settlement from its ruthless oppressors and, when they do, they discover that the Azlanti have taken away one of the settlers of Nakondis, an old friend of theirs, and an experimental spaceship engine discovered on the planet. Will our heroes be able to save Cedona and keep the experimental engine away from the clutches of the Azlanti or will they be crushed by the power of the Throne of the Aeons like the many who dared to challenge it?

This collection includes the entire Throne of Aeons Cycle and includes:

• "The Extension of the Empire", a Starfinder adventure for 1st level characters, by Ron Lundeen.

• "Escape from the Moon Prison", a Starfinder adventure for 3rd level characters, by Eleanor Ferron.

• "The Rune Engine Stratagem", a Starfinder adventure for 5th level characters, by Larry Wilhelm.

• An archive of new and fascinating creatures, from radioactive dragons to giant clouds of devouring slime, by Patrick Brennan, Ron Lundeen, Joe Pasini, Owen KC Stephens, Eleanor Ferron, David N. Ross, Ian Eller and Larry Wilhelm.

• The history and description of Nakondis, a colony of the Coven Worlds, and of Madelon's Landing, his most important settlement, as well as a new theme of the characters, the colonizer, by Ron Lundeen, plus a glimpse of the home planet of the 'Azlanti Star Empire, by Owen KC Stephens.

• A collection of advanced spaceships built and piloted in the Alzanti Stellar Empire, by Lyz Liddell, the statistics and plans of a new exploratory vessel of the Alzanti Stellar Empire, by Ron Lundeen, a luxurious royal vessel Azlanti, by Larry Wilhelm, as well as an Azlanti spaceship, and finally a look at a space station on the edge of the Star Empire, by Eleanor Ferron.

• An in-depth look at the culture, history and territories of the expansionist Star Empire Azlanti, as well as a collection of magical and technological Azlanti equipment, by Robert G. McCreary, with Jason Keeley and Lyz Liddell.

• Advice on how to continue the campaign after the final confrontation and indications on the power that the Azlanti Star Empire would acquire if the heroes were to fail, by Tracy Barnett.

• And much more!

boardgame.name: Nachtschwärmer
boardgame.description:
100% handcrafted, every game is 100% one of a kind, 100% made with love and passion in Cologne, Germany,

In Nachtschwärmer ("Night Owls"), each player is a moth that wants to reach the light in the center of the table before anyone else — but moths don't fly in a straight line, so you need to figure out how to wiggle well to win.

The game consists of one six-sided die and eight bar coasters: one a "flying" disc that has arcs marked 1, 2, 3, and 4 along its edge and seven moth/light discs. Each player takes a coaster and places it moth-side up in front of them, while one coast is placed light-side up equidistant from all players. The moth side of a coaster has two black lines intersecting the perimeter (180º apart) and a red line every 22.5º around the perimeter.

On your turn, announce a number from 1 to 6, then roll the die. If you guess correctly, you advance your moth, possibly take a second turn, or even send a player back to start; if you guess incorrectly, you might still advance (although not as much) or another player might move instead of you.

To move your moth, take the flying disc and place the edge of the 1, 2, 3 or 4 space (depending on what you rolled) adjacent to one of the black edges on the perimeter of your moth disc, then roll your moth disc until a red line on your disc hits the other black edge of the 1, 2, 3 or 4 space. The higher the number, the farther your moth will move — albeit in a curved manner instead of straight toward the light.

No disc can ever be placed on top of another, so if a moth is blocking your way, then you must fly elsewhere! Whoever first touches their moth to the light disc wins!

Nachtschwärmer includes three variants, one of which has you start the game with several obstacles in play, say pretzels or gummis. Any time you hit an obstacle, you must eat it, then return your moth to its starting point.

listing.notes: Limited Edition Number 99/100.
Deluxe Versiin inklusive Poster, Beutel und Flaschenöffner!!!

boardgame.name: If Dreams Could Kill
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

If Dreams Could Kill is the ultimate expansion for diversifying player options to help players both experienced and new get the most out of their City of Mist experience.

Unlike the other expansions from Shadows & Showdowns, which focus on fleshing out the City setting, If Dreams Could Kill focuses on the players by providing them more ways with which to express and evolve their characters.

What's inside:

Six (6) new themebooks: Conjuration, Destiny, Enclave, Familiar, Struggle, and Turf. Expanding the system's built-in character customization even further and growing the number of available themebooks to 27!
A character concept guide for quick and easy character building, complete with character creation tables using Legendary Archetypes and Noir Tropes to choose from, making character creation almost effortless for new players.
50 new veteran improvements: everything from gaining deeper Mist awareness and control to enhancing your character's Mythos abilities; increasing deduction skills or conflict resolution capabilities; and plenty of highly-cinematic feats of pure baddassery!
24 ready-to-use Relic and Familiar theme kits that you can add to your character as extra themes, giving her access to new Mythos power sets

boardgame.name: Escape the Dark Sector: Mission Playmat
boardgame.description:
There is a lot going on in the mission area during a game of Escape the Dark Sector. Add a bit of 'mission control' to your experience with this evocative playmat.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Frontline
boardgame.description:
Frontline is a two player card game representing a battle between two armies using highly detailed illustrated cards. The aim of the game is to defeat the opposing players commander by first breaking through their ranks of soldiers, whilst defending your own commander at the same time.
Cards are randomly placed at the start of the game, meaning strategies and tactics will have to be adapted and improvised as each battle unfolds, making every game unique, interesting and engaging.

Easy to understand but difficult to master, with elements of luck thrown in to the mix. Frontline makes each battle diverse and unpredictable.

Use specific cards skills and abilities to gain an upper hand against your opponent, there is no one strategy to win the war!

Stunning illustrations on each card emphasise the raw, gritty feel of being on the battlefield, and make every victory feel truly earned.

The highs and lows of battle. The ability to have your back against a wall as your opponent smashes through your defences, only to have one of his commanders guards flee, potentially changing the course of the battle makes each game truly tense and memorable.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Lua Cheia
boardgame.description:
Lua Cheia is a trick-taking game for two players, using a deck of 15 cards. Each player receives a 6 card hand, and the remaining three cards are not revealed.

Each trick is "may follow" and resolved after each player has played one card. If the cards are of the same suit, the player with the lower ranked card loses an amount of life equal to the difference of the card ranks. If the cards are of different suits, the second player loses an amount of life equal to the rank of the lead player's card.

At the end of a hand, the players' remaining life values are evaluated. If one player has been KO'd, the other player earns 3 points; otherwise, the player with the most life earns 1 point. Prepare a new round, with renewed life totals, and play until one player has earned at least 7 points; the player with the most points wins.

boardgame.name: Pinball Dreams 2
Pinball Dreams II
boardgame.description:
Pinball Dreams 2

An alternate PC-only sequel, Pinball Dreams 2, was released in 1995 by 21st Century Entertainment (like Pinball Dreams) but was developed by Spidersoft.

It includes four tables:

"Neptune", themed to underwater exploration.
"Safari", themed to an African safari.
"Revenge of the Robot Warriors", themed to a battle against robots.
"Stall Turn", themed to aerobatics.

Composer Andrew Barnabas did not have access to the game while writing its music, and was instead given only a list of song titles and a copy of the original Pinball Dreams. He complained that "I couldn't even see what the game looked like. It was like composing in the dark."

Source: Wikipedia, "Pinball Dreams", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Subclasses, Part 4
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Two spooky subclasses manifest in today’s Unearthed Arcana: the College of Spirits for bards and the Undead patron for warlocks.

boardgame.name: Pinball Arcade
Pinball Dreams Deluxe
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Compilation of the two Pinball Dreams games gives you eight tables to play on.

boardgame.name: Pinball Gold Pack
Pinball Power Pack
boardgame.description:
Back of the box

The pinball wizards at 21st Century Entertainment are the only people who can deliver 20 quality pinball tables in one package!

boardgame.name: Sailing Alone at Sea
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Sailing Alone at Sea is a hack of Takuma Okada's Alone Among the Stars.

This is a journaling game requiring one player, a pack of 52 standard playing cards and a six-sided die (1d6) or another suitable randomizer.

Finally, you have got the small sailing ship you have always dreamed of and set sail by yourself on the ocean, travelling to different places. You have no fixed destination in mind, heading where the winds and waves take you, only using the small motor when you have no other choice. You travel from place, experiencing the sights that the ocean has to offer and writing down what you see in your ship's log.

boardgame.name: Fantasy City Block 01: Artisan's Square
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

You weave your way through the heavy crowd of mid day as your traveling companions await your arrival at the gem cutter’s shop. Tucked away in a small sack are a dozen raw blue gemstones that you found jutting out of a cave wall. Suddenly, just as you narrowly dodge a carter’s donkey you feel a tug at your side. Someone is trying to steal your stones!
You quickly swivel to face the scoundrel as you unsheath your trusty dagger. A filthy young ruffian’s eyes widen at the sight of your blade as their hand quickly releases its grip on your sack. Your eyes narrow in anger. Suddenly you feel a heavy gloved hand on your shoulder. You quickly turn to meet the grim face of one of the local watchmen.
“At ease, traveler..”, the watchmen says as one of his companions stop the would be thief from fleeing, “Put away your blade. We’ll take over from here.”
Just another day in the city.

Welcome to Artisan’s Square, the first installment of the Fantasy City Block series by authors Dan “Smif” Smith and Dave Woodrum. This drop in urban fantasy location can be used in any of your current campaign world cities or connected to future series releases to make a whole new city for your player characters to explore.
Each Fantasy City Block release details a small block sized chunk of a bustling high fantasy metropolis. The various occupants, merchants, and landmarks of the city block locations are given flavorful descriptions, allowing the Game Master (GM) to add a great deal of color to the world that they are immersing the players in.
The first edition of this series focuses on a small chunk of the city that is home to craftsmen and supporting vendors. This installment, like others in the series, provide the following components.

Player and Master Maps: There are two maps presented in this book. One is for the players and lacks details regarding what is in each building. The master map provides a basic one to three word designation for each important locality, such as “arrows”, “healer”, “tavern”, etc.

Map Locations: A large portion of this product is devoted to providing detailed textural descriptions of the marked locations on the master map. Here you’ll find information about the non-player characters (NPCs) who live and/or work at these locations as well as a few notes about prices, inventory, etc.

Random Street Encounter Charts: Some of the most interesting things in Artisan’s Square occurs on the streets! List making veteran Dave Woodrum has provided three different twenty sider driven charts for random street encounters. The first chart deals with day encounters (early dawn to around 5pm equivalent), the second evening encounters (after 5pmish until midnight), and the third night encounters (after midnight to early dawn).

Random Rumors and Gossip Chart: Don’t put away that twenty sider just yet… there’s an additional chart for rumors and gossip. While most things that an eavesdropper might hear in Artisan’s Square are true there’s a few things that are half truths or flat out lies. This chart provides twenty different things that a character might hear along with information about their truthfulness (or not).

Battle Map: Each installment contains an 11” x17” scaled battle map that the GM can print off and use with miniatures or tokens on the gaming table. This map is provided as a separate pdf file from this core supplement book.

Tokens: An exquisite value for the common gaming table! Smif has so kindly provided complimentary tokens for you to cut out and use with the battle map if you don’t have miniatures. These are in a separate pdf and it is recommended that heavier card stock paper is used for these if you have such.

boardgame.name: Na skrzydłach: Dwustronna mata do gry
Wingspan: Neoprene Player Mat
boardgame.description: Neoprene Player Mats to replace the cardboard mats in the game.

boardgame.name: Jigūan: The Eastern Mechanist – New Resource Tracks
boardgame.description:
Comes with 4 players markers and one double-sided resource track.

There are two sides to the New Resource Tracks: Immediate Rewards and Gear Exchange Rewards. At the start of the game, decide which side to use and place beside the Five-Pagoda board. All players will use this side during the game.

boardgame.name: Battlefold: Lion Heart Legendary Sword
boardgame.description:
At the beginning of the game, the Sword miniature is placed in the middle of the game board.

The first player to land on the space where Lion Heart is takes the sword.

The player who takes the sword has a permanent increase of attack power by 1.

If the player who has the sword dies, the sword is also taken away by attacking player.

If the player who has the sword dies via a trap, the sword falls onto this space on the board.

Ghosts cannot take the sword.

listing.notes:
unplayed
Sold together with basegame

boardgame.name: Fistful of Lead: Starfighters!
boardgame.description:
Fistful of Lead fans asked for a space fighter game and here it is - Fistful of Lead: Starfighters!

As with previous Fistful of Lead rules each player only needs 5 or 6 miniature ships per player to start gaming.
You can play 1-on-1 games or larger skirmishes with up to 6 or 8 players.

This book contains rules for building your flight and how to set up different scenarios.
A few genre options are provided to get you started as well as rules for fleet sized ships..
Most players of any age will pick up the game mechanics quickly, even those who have never played a wargame before.

Starfighters! was not meant with any particular miniature line in mind. You can use whatever miniature space ships you have. There are many popular lines out there to choose from and some are very affordable on discount sites.

This IS NOT a theoretical recreation of fighter on fighter space combat, but rather a Hollywood take on dogfighting in the dark depths of space.

This IS a great way to spend an hour or two having fun with your friends, playing with spaceships and yelling "PEW! PEW! PEW!"

-description from publisher

boardgame.name: The Last Hundred Yards Volume 3: The Solomon Islands
boardgame.description:
The Last Hundred Yards Vol. 3: The Solomon Islands is the third game in the Last Hundred Yards Series. This game focuses on the vicious and brutal Solomons Campaign, including actions to control the islands of Guadalcanal, Bougainville, and New Georgia.

When you play the Solomon Islands Campaign missions, you will experience some of the fiercest small unit actions in the Pacific Theater. The game will focus on actions involving the 1st (The Old Breed) and 3rd (Fighting Third) Marine Divisions, as well as the Army’s 25th Infantry Division—the unit that finally drove the Japanese off the island, earning them the nickname “Tropic Lightning.”
Take to the jungles of Guadalcanal with the 1st Marine Division as they begin the first ground offensive of the war. Landed onto Guadalcanal and with intermittent naval support as the struggle for naval supremacy raged offshore, the Marines fought tooth and nail to secure their small foothold around Henderson Airfield. They fought against Japanese Reinforcements coming from all over the South Pacific area. Engage in bitter jungle fighting with the 3rd Marine Division as they attempt to hold and expand the beachhead on Bougainville Island against the Imperial Japanese 6th Infantry Division.

Finally, serve with the 25th Infantry Division’s famed 27th Regiment, the “Wolfhounds,” as they try to reduce Japanese positions on Guadalcanal’s Galloping Horse Ridge (an action that is portrayed in the movie “The Thin Red Line”). You will also fight with the Wolfhounds in the jungle around Munda Point for the airfield on New Georgia. Each of these actions involved tense jungle warfare and the routing out of fanatical Japanese units from hidden bunkers and pillboxes. You will understand the nerve-racking frustration of clearing an enemy position, only to have infiltrators attack you yet again from a different direction, at night!
This volume introduces new weapons and terrain including flamethrowers, anti-tank halftracks, light and heavy jungle. Each mission will provide new challenges with different elements, forces, and situations encountered, making this volume an exciting and nail-biting addition to The Last Hundred Yard Series.

This game is a stand alone game. It does NOT require ownership of The Last Hundred Yards to be played.

boardgame.name: Motor Sport
boardgame.description:
Motor Sport is a replay style game, where anyone can recreate a sports car race if they know the starting grid and finishing order. The game is a pen and paper type of game, with no display offered or required.

The game is structured to last six turns, and the game offers three layers of complexity. Each turn consists of an action phase, followed by a consolidation phase. A deck of cards drives the sequencing of when drivers act. On every turn, each driver has a D6 rolled to check if they have some sort of driving incident (improvements and detrimental problems). If an incident is triggered, it is immediately resolved. Otherwise, drivers who have a normal turn are resolved in the consolidation phase.

After six turns the race is completed, and the winning driver is noted. Motorsport allows players to easily rerun entire series of races from Formula 1, Indy, Nascar and other racing series. Real-world results (qualifying and final standings) inform the statistics that drive the game.

—user summary

boardgame.name: The Obscure: A Sinister Adventure
O Obscuro: Uma Aventura Sinistra
boardgame.description:
The Obscure - A Sinister Adventure is a cooperative board game where you will be part of a group that has noticed strange things happening in the city of Meradosia, mysterious signs that something bad is about to happen. Traveling around the city, you will have to investigate clues from stories told by witnesses of supernatural events, face terrible creatures and also discover the whereabouts of the Crystals of Doom and prepare to face the much-feared Obscure.

In this game, you will be one of the characters and will have to get enough clues to solve the Adventure cards, being able to overcome the challenges to conquer the Crystals of Doom, which will be responsible for exposing the vulnerability of the game's biggest enemy, the Obscure. However, it’s not just about moving back and forth, you have to be very careful, because in addition to the possibility of the map being infested by creatures, you need to worry about not losing the tracks and also keeping the creatures away from the active areas - area named on the map. Phew phew, it will be a challenge.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: The Call of Karen
boardgame.description: The Call of Karen is a PC simulation comedy game about a 1950s suburban housewife whose home is being invaded by Cthulhu. You play as said housewife, Karen, who is trapped in an unhappy marriage taking care of an ungrateful child, and is faced with the struggle of keeping up appearances in the face of a home gone mad. Play through tasks that a suburban mom would do as her house slowly descends into chaos!

boardgame.name: Engage & Destroy: Volume 1
boardgame.description:
Engage & Destroy is a simulation game of tactical armored warfare in World War II, 1939 to 1945.
Underlying Engage & Destroy is a comprehensive set of models that generates the game data for each of the units used in the game so that the game subsumes most of the complex calculations allowing the players to focus primarily on combat tactics.

Players play in turns using pulses, with each turn representing two minutes of actual time. Players draw and play chits, the interaction between them outlines who can move and engage with their units. When all units in the game have moved and/or performed a combat action, or both Players consecutively PASS the turn ends. Combat is instantaneous.

Engage & Destroy combat situations are presented in near-historical context, which balance resources and capabilities between the players making the game contest of skill rather than a match between unbalanced order of battles, allowing the game to portray period type engagements in a skill contest format.

There are three types of games in Engage & Destroy:

Meeting Engagements - players must take and hold locations, gaining more points than their opponent before the game ends,
Assault - one player must push a defender back behind a series of defense lines before the game ends,
Firefight - In Arena, it’s a pure shoot out, with the player who earns the most “kill” points winning by game’s end.


Scale:
Complexity: Medium
Time Scale: 2 minutes/turn
Map Scale: 175 metres per hex
Unit Scale: Single Vehicle or Team
Players: 2
Solitaire Suitability: Medium
Playing Time: 1 to 4 hours

boardgame.description:
A spin-off from the popular Lost World Combat Book series. Instead of fantasy heroes, the players take the roles of fighting Dinosaurs.

Each player neeeds a booklet to play. Booklets are traded and, as each player selects a move, a reference grid determines the result (wounds loss, off balance maneuvers, and so on). Combat continues until one Dinosaur or the other expires.

boardgame.name: Lost Worlds: "Thorgal" the Wyrm Slayer
boardgame.description:
Lost Worlds is the most popular entry in Alfred Leonardi's line of book games, which also includes Ace of Aces. Each player has a character card and a booklet (and sometimes special Tactics, Luck, or Spell cards) for one of about fifty (and growing) medieval-fantasy characters. Characters can range from barbarian warriors to animated skeletons to elven archers to unicorns — even two different dragons. Booklets are traded and, as each player selects a move, a reference grid in the books determine the results (wounds, off-balance maneuvers, and so on). Combat continues until one fighter or the other expires.

An interesting feature of the Lost Worlds system is that, under some versions of the rules, characters may improve their abilities as they gain experience. In theory, you are supposed to keep track of your progress with each character, and if one is utterly killed, it will have to start over without its improved skills.

Part of the Lost Worlds series of books.

Lost Worlds is the most popular entry in Alfred Leonardi's line of book games, which also includes Ace of Aces. Each player has a character card and a booklet (and sometimes special Tactics, Luck, or Spell cards) for one of about fifty (and growing) medieval-fantasy characters. Characters can range from barbarian warriors to animated skeletons to elven archers to unicorns — even two different dragons. Booklets are traded and, as each player selects a move, a reference grid in the books determine the results (wounds, off-balance maneuvers, and so on). Combat continues until one fighter or the other expires.

An interesting feature of the Lost Worlds system is that, under some versions of the rules, characters may improve their abilities as they gain experience. In theory, you are supposed to keep track of your progress with each character, and if one is utterly killed, it will have to start over without its improved skills.

Part of the Lost Worlds series of books.

boardgame.name: Kanaloa
boardgame.description:
Aloha! Adventures sail the oceans and hope to gain the favour of Kanaloa, the god of water, to get ahead fastest. He sends his spirits of the four elements, the Tikis, to assist them. But the Tikis' head are filled with nonsense and they try to trump each other. Kanaloa himself has to intervene to get everything back in line and protect the sailors from the danger of the shallows, the octopus. Who will claim victory with the help of the right Tikis and sail towards the sunset as the lucky winner?

Aim of the game:
The aim is to take the most tricks by skillfully playing cards to get ahead as fast as possible with your boat and to outrun the slowest player.

Gameplay:
The game consists of several rounds. One round is always played as follows:

The starting player opens a round by playing a card from their hand.
The other players now also play one card each in turn.
Check to see who took the trick. This player may move their boat forward to the next free water space. Any occupied spaces are skipped.
Before the player who has taken the trick plays a card for the next trick, they announce the trump suit for the next trick out loud. The suit on the water space on which the leading boat is placed is always trumps.
A round is finished once all cards have been played and 8 tricks have been taken.
After the player who took the last trick has moved their boat forward, they remove any free water card from the sea route. So the sailing route gets shorter and shorter during the game.
The player who took the last trick starts the next round. They shuffle all the cards, deal 8 cards to each player and lay a card for the first trick.


The game ends when a player‘s boat laps the last boat on the sea route. This player wins the game.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: TRES
トレス
boardgame.description:
TRES is an abstract strategy game for two players, played on a hex grid, with stickered metal nuts.

Each player receives 12 nuts, four each of values 1, 2, and 3. The nuts start in a player's home row, placed in four stacks, with 1 on the bottom, 2 above that, and 3 atop.

On their turn, a player may move one of their nuts from the top of a stack forward (never backwards). Pieces may land on empty spaces or nuts of a lower value (of either player) than the moving piece. Pieces may jump over stacks of nuts equal to the moving piece's value or higher.

If a piece if moved forward again from an opponent's home row, that piece is removed from the game and the player earns a number of points equal to the value printed on the nut's sticker.

The first player to 15 (or more) points wins.

boardgame.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – Tarkin Initiative Labs Skirmish Map
boardgame.description:
The Tarkin Initiative Labs Skirmish Map sees players battling throughout the labs of the secret facility that developed the dreaded Death Star battle stations!

The Tarkin Initiative Labs Skirmish Map also comes with two different Skirmish cards for easy reference that see players battling to shut down a rogue AI or trying to collect as many abandoned weapons as possible. With your games played out beside beautiful art of a Rebel hero and the menacing visages of BT-1 and 0-0-0, you'll be drawn into the Star Wars galaxy like never before.

The Tarkin Initiative created two of the most infamous weapons in the Star Wars galaxy; now, the Initiative’s labs are yours to do battle in.

This 26- by-26 slip-resistant mat provides plenty of space for both your figures and various tokens to occupy, and allows you to jump into your Imperial Assault skirmish game with ease.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Clever Cubed
Clever hoch Drei
Clever tot de 3e macht
Très futé à la puissance trois
boardgame.description:
Clever hoch drei features the same gameplay as Ganz schön clever and Doppelt so clever, but with new categories in which to score — sometimes with several dice at the same time.

Your goal: Choose dice, then place the numbers into the matching colored area, put together tricky chain-scoring opportunities, and rack up the points. The dice you don't use are as important as what you do because every die that's smaller than the chosen one can be used by the other players, keeping everyone in the game at all times.

boardgame.name: Diuna: Imperium
Duna: Impérium
Dune: Imperium
Dűne: Impérium
Дюна: Імперіум
Дюна: Империя
デューン 砂の惑星 インペリウム
듄: 임페리움
boardgame.description:
Some important links: The Official FAQ, the Unofficial FAQ, and an Automa (solo and 2p) Overview

Dune: Imperium is a game that finds inspiration in elements and characters from the Dune legacy, both the new film from Legendary Pictures and the seminal literary series from Frank Herbert, Brian Herbert, and Kevin J. Anderson.

As a leader of one of the Great Houses of the Landsraad, raise your banner and marshal your forces and spies. War is coming, and at the center of the conflict is Arrakis – Dune, the desert planet.

Dune: Imperium uses deck-building to add a hidden-information angle to traditional worker placement.

You start with a unique leader card, as well as a deck identical to those of your opponents. As you acquire cards and build your deck, your choices will define your strengths and weaknesses. Cards allow you to send your Agents to certain spaces on the game board, so how your deck evolves affects your strategy. You might become more powerful militarily, able to deploy more troops than your opponents. Or you might acquire cards that give you an edge with the four political factions represented in the game: the Emperor, the Spacing Guild, the Bene Gesserit, and the Fremen.

Unlike many deck-building games, you don’t play your entire hand in one turn. Instead, you draw a hand of cards at the start of every round and alternate with other players, taking one Agent turn at a time (playing one card to send one of your Agents to the game board). When it’s your turn and you have no more Agents to place, you’ll take a Reveal turn, revealing the rest of your cards, which will provide Persuasion and Swords. Persuasion is used to acquire more cards, and Swords help your troops fight for the current round’s rewards as shown on the revealed Conflict card.

Defeat your rivals in combat, shrewdly navigate the political factions, and acquire precious cards. The Spice must flow to lead your House to victory!

SKU : DWD01000
Dune Imperium Board Game New
Dune: Imperium Is a Game that Finds Inspiration in Elements and Characters from The Dune Legacy, Both the New Film from Legendary Pictures and The Seminal Literary Series from Frank Herbert, Brian Herbert, and Kevin J. Anderson.
As a Leader of One of The Great Houses of The Landsraad, Raise Your Banner and Marshal Your Forces and Spies. War Is Coming, and At the Center of The Conflict Is Arrakis – Dune, the Desert Planet.
Dune: Imperium Uses Deck-Building to Add a Hidden-Information Angle to Traditional Worker Placement.
You Start with A Unique Leader Card, as Well as Deck Identical to Those of Your Opponents. as You Acquire Cards and Build Your Deck, Your Choices Will Define Your Strengths and Weaknesses. Cards Allow You to Send Your Agents to Certain Spaces on The Game Board, so How Your Deck Evolves Affects Your Strategy. You Might Become More Powerful Militarily, Able to Deploy More Troops than Your Opponents. or You Might Acquire Cards that Give You an Edge with The Four Political Factions Represented in The Game: The Emperor, the Spacing Guild, the Bene Gesserit, and The Fremen.
Unlike Many Deck-Building Games, You Don’t Play Your Entire Hand in One Turn. Instead, You Draw a Hand of Cards at The Start of Every Round and Alternate with Other Players, Taking One Agent Turn at A Time (playing One Card to Send One of Your Agents to The Game Board). when It’s Your Turn and You Have No More Agents to Place, You’ll Take a Reveal Turn, Revealing the Rest of Your Cards, Which Will Provide Persuasion and Swords. Persuasion Is Used to Acquire More Cards, and Swords Help Your Troops Fight for The Current Round’s Rewards as Shown on The Revealed Conflict Card.
Defeat Your Rivals in Combat, Shrewdly Navigate the Political Factions, and Acquire Precious the Spice Must Flow Cards to Lead Your House to Victory!

boardgame.name: The Umbrella Academy Game
boardgame.description:
The Umbrella Academy Game brings the captivating world that Gerard Way and Gabriel Bá created to your tabletop and lets you play as the seven siblings who possess unusual powers in a fun and exciting card game.

In the game, each player picks their favorite family member to act as their hero card, then places a life card underneath it. Each player gets five hero attack cards. Shuffle the villain cards and place them in the middle of the play area. Put the deck of villain attack cards and the deck of dysfunctional family cards next to the villain cards. Put the final battle cards to the side.

The first player takes the turn marker card and turns over the top dysfunctional family card, which affects this round of the game. Lay out the number of villain attack cards as shown on the first villain card. Now each player takes their turn, beginning with the player with the marker card. Players pick a card from their hand to attack a villain, heal their hero, or put a hero story card into effect. Once all the villain attack cards have a hero attack card played under them, players can use their hero's special ability.

Gameplay proceeds until all the villains have been defeated (or no family members are alive). Then it's time for the final battle. The defeated villains come back to life and players attack!

There are updated rules available at http://umbrellaacademygame.com

boardgame.name: Phantom Signal
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Using power stations and mining minerals, you build a network or weapons and energy holding stations to fight enemy ships. By using research points, you increase the special powers you can use. You follow a campaign tree to advance the plot towards the source of the signal.

boardgame.name: Ganz Schön Clever: Ersatzblock
That's Pretty Clever!: Replacement Pad
Trés Futé!: Blocs Supplémentaires
boardgame.description: Replacement block for Ganz Schön Clever!

boardgame.name: Doppelt so Clever: Ersatzblockk
Twice as Clever!: Replacement Pad
Vraiment très Futé!: Bloc Supplémentaire
boardgame.description: Replacement block for Twice as Clever!

boardgame.name: Nightwatch: Terror and Treasure in the Dark Corners of the World
boardgame.description:
NIGHTWATCH is a game about killing monsters. All kinds, anywhere, any time.

You and your friends are members of the NIGHTWATCH: an ancient order of warriors, trackers, wizards, and alchemists dedicated to hunting down and destroying the malevolent creatures that terrorize humanity.

Over the course of the game, your characters will rise through the ranks of their chosen Guild, gaining experience and unlocking new skills as they fight ever more dangerous enemies on the blood-soaked path to confront their ultimate quarry.

Miniatures agnostic and adaptable to nearly any fantasy setting from Ancients to Black Powder, NIGHTWATCH is easy to learn and quick to play, with straightforward dice mechanics and minimal book keeping.

Made for Cooperative or Solo gaming, you can read the book in an afternoon and gather your friends, your dice, terrain, and miniatures that evening for your first hunt.

These rules are a framework for you to build your own tales of heart-stopping bravery, foul treachery, cringe-worthy cowardice, and most of all, epic victories against overwhelming odds.

So sharpen your sword, check the flints on your pistols, and grab a healing potion; it’s time to give the monsters something to fear.

—description from the publisher
